results.title: Science international. No. 2. The last scourge
results.creator_credit: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A report on the world-wide investigations into the origins of life, as revealed in the study of the cell, and progress in the battle against cancer. British, American, French and Russian scientists tell of current lines of research into the origins of cancer in the light of what has already been discovered about the cell. The clinical aspects of cancer are not dealt with.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV

results.title: Science international. No. 1. What is life?
results.creator_credit: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A report on the world-wide investigation into the origins of life, as revealed in the study of the cell, and progress in the battle against cancer. Explains what is known of the nature, operation, and origin of the living human cell. Interviews and demonstrations involve scientists from Britain, the United States, France and the Soviet Union. Extensive use is made of a model of a living cell enlarged a million times.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV

results.title: Science in the orchestra
results.creator_credit: Alex Strasser, Dorothy Grayson, Brian Smith, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Realist Films
results.brief_description: An exposition of the physics of orchestral sound for young people and adults. Conductor Muir Mathieson of the London Symphony Orchestra, and a physics demonstrator reveal facts about sound which fall into three sections, namely, 1. hearing the orchestra; 2. exploring the instruments; 3. looking at sounds.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Strasser, Dorothy Grayson, Brian Smith, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Realist Films

results.title: Science in a wine glass
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Shows in detail, through specially made glass tanks, how wine is fermented, how fermentation is arrested, how color is infused into the red wine from skin pigmentation, how champagne is made and how wine matures. Also demonstrates how cross-pollination is effected to produce new varieties of grapes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions

results.title: Science goes wool-growing
results.creator_credit: Roland Litchfield, Litchfield TV, Cinesound and Pagewood Studios
results.brief_description: Deals with the use of chemicals and fertilisers in sheep raising. Opening with shots of the Commonwealth Fertilisers and Chemicals Ltd factory at Yarraville, Victoria, shows the manufacture of super-phosphate and other agricultural products. Reviews research and experimental work associated with the development of new materials. Describes ways in which graziers can achieve maximum benefit from chemicals and fertilisers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roland Litchfield, Litchfield TV, Cinesound and Pagewood Studios

results.title: Science goes fishing
results.brief_description: Scientists from Laval University and the Federal Fisheries Research Board carry on scientific research in Gaspe to improve cod-fishing. The film tells how much time and patience were needed before the fishing folk of the area would accept scientific methods of fishing.

results.title: Science frontier = Frontieres de la science
results.creator_credit: Christina L McCaughey and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film that shows the civilian application of technology developed by the Research Section of the Department of National Defense such as: SONAR respirators; Malcolm Horizon; freeze-dried food; cathodic hull protection; and combat glasses.

results.title: Science for the tropics
results.creator_credit: Tony Baker, Richard Tamblind and Technical and Scientific Films
results.brief_description: A look at the work of the Tropical Products Institute in London, an organisation which assists third world countries to exploit their natural resources commercially. The Institute also does much laboratory work relating to agricultural issues. The film contains quite technical examinations of several projects the Institute has been involved in.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Baker, Richard Tamblind and Technical and Scientific Films

results.title: Science for the space age: waves and energy
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner, Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains that there are many kinds of waves, including water, sound, light and radio waves. Uses illustrations and experiments to show how waves carry energy from one place to another. Describes the relationship between frequency and wave length; and explains how radio waves carry information.

results.title: Science for life
results.creator_credit: Peace Committee of the Society of Friends (Quakers) and Knight Films
results.brief_description: A teenage schoolboy is engaged in the quest for scientific knowledge. Two senior scientists bring the boy face to face with the challeng of - science to what end - life or death? A straightforward dramatisation of a debate intended to arouse lively and useful discussion for teenage audiences.
